justification: Moderate size (LOC 104) and complexity (WMC 22) for a base/abstract reader. It has a reasonable number of methods (nom 12) and moderate cohesion (LCOM 0.5), indicating it likely encapsulates shared behavior rather than multiple unrelated responsibilities.

Utility-style class with small surface (nom 3) and modest LOC (64). Although WMC is 14, the limited number of methods and its role as a helper indicate focused responsibilities rather than a bloated abstraction.
Small data/structure class (LOC 32, WMC 7, nom 6) with focused dependencies. Metrics show it is lightweight and cohesive (LCOM 0.0), not indicative of insufficient modularization.

Strong indication of insufficient modularization: very large (LOC 362), very high complexity (WMC 73), and many fields (nof 9). It depends on many other concerns (decoding, math utilities, result handling, finder patterns), suggesting multiple responsibilities concentrated in one class and a bloated implementation that would benefit from decomposition.
Very small and simple (LOC 30, WMC 7, nom 6) with focused purpose and dependencies. Metrics indicate a cohesive, narrowly scoped abstraction.
Tiny helper/data class (LOC 17, WMC 4, nom 4, DIT 1) with focused role. Metrics do not show signs of excessive size or mixed responsibilities.

Very large size (LOC 350) with many methods (nom 18) and very high cyclomatic complexity (WMC 102); many dependencies and varied responsibilities related to parsing/decoding indicate the class concentrates multiple concerns and is a likely candidate for decomposition.
Small footprint (LOC 19), few methods, and limited dependencies; appears focused on a narrow decoding responsibility.
Small class (LOC 24) with few methods and limited dependencies, indicating a focused responsibility.

Relatively large (LOC 244) with moderate complexity (WMC 18) and several fields; performs parsing logic closely tied to decoding and collaborates heavily with GeneralAppIdDecoder, suggesting multiple parsing responsibilities that could be split for clarity and maintainability.
Very small helper nested type (LOC 14) that appears limited in scope and purpose.
Small class (LOC 30) with a few methods and clear purpose (holding decoded info); responsibilities appear cohesive.
Tiny class (LOC 21) representing a parsed-block result; focused data-holder role with limited complexity.
Small state-tracking class (LOC 39) with concentrated responsibility for parsing state management; size and intent are cohesive.
Minimal nested type (LOC 1) serving as an enumeration/marker; not a modularization concern.
Small implementation (LOC 23) with a limited set of methods focused on a single decoding variant.
Compact class (LOC 22) with few methods and focused functionality.
Moderate size (LOC 41) but limited number of methods and clear decoding purpose; does not on its own indicate excessive responsibilities.
Very small (LOC 14) and appears focused on a specific decoding task.
Small class (LOC 19) with few methods; responsibility appears narrow and cohesive.
Small data/utility class (LOC 32) with limited methods; focused on numeric decoding representation.
Tiny holder type (LOC 12) with minimal functionality; not indicative of insufficient modularization.
Small decoder (LOC 33) with limited methods and dependencies; appears cohesive.
Very small (LOC 14) specialized decoder; responsibilities are narrow.
Small class (LOC 18) likely representing a simple decoded character; focused role.

Moderate size (LOC 49) but serves as an abstraction/base for decoders; although its WMC (19) is notable, its role as a central abstract component is appropriate and does not by itself indicate poor modularization.
Relatively small to moderate (LOC 61, WMC 10) and appears to implement a specific decoding variant; responsibilities seem contained.
Very small class (loc 39, nom 3, wmc 7) with few responsibilities; metrics and dependencies indicate a focused role (value holder used by scanners), so it appears adequately modularized.
Compact data-holder (loc 32, nom 6, wmc 6) representing barcode metadata; low complexity and cohesive purpose indicate no evidence of insufficient modularization.

Extremely large and complex (loc 479, nom 30, wmc 115) and depends on multiple decoding concerns and modes; this concentration of decoding logic across many methods and modes suggests multiple responsibilities that could be decomposed (parsing modes, ECI handling, data interpretation).
Tiny nested enum (loc 1) representing parsing modes; single, well-scoped responsibility—no modularization issue.

Moderate size (loc 117, nom 12, wmc 23) but represents a clear geometric abstraction (bounding box) with focused responsibilities; complexity appears appropriate for its role, indicating acceptable modularization.

Relatively large and complex for a column abstraction (loc 190, nom 9, wmc 45) and interacts with many decoder and metadata classes; the size and complexity imply it may aggregate multiple responsibilities (indicator parsing, metadata extraction, alignment), making it a candidate for decomposition.

Very large and complex central class (loc 455, nom 25, wmc 108) that coordinates scanning, error correction, codeword decoding and result assembly across many dependencies; this concentration of scanning and decoding behavior indicates multiple responsibilities that could be split into smaller cohesive components.
Small/concise representation (loc 50, nom 12, wmc 12) modeling a single concept (codeword) with limited responsibilities and clear dependencies—no sign of bloated interface or mixed responsibilities.

Focused decoder utility (loc 86, nom 6, wmc 17) that performs codeword decoding using math utilities; despite moderate complexity it has a single well-defined concern and does not appear to conflate unrelated responsibilities.
Relatively small (loc 63, nom 8, wmc 16) and models a column in the detection result; responsibilities appear cohesive and limited, suggesting acceptable modularization.

Substantially sized aggregation (loc 238, nom 19, wmc 61) that manages columns, metadata and bounding operations; metric profile and its aggregating role suggest it groups multiple responsibilities (management, reconciliation, manipulation) that could be separated for clarity and easier maintenance.

Very large and complex class: LOC=529, WMC=112, NOM=29, NOF=25. Low cohesion (LCOM≈0.10) and many diverse dependencies (camera, decode thread/handler, UI/Viewfinder, history, preferences, beep, ambient light, clipboard, result handlers, etc.), indicating it concentrates multiple responsibilities (UI, camera control, decoding orchestration, result handling, history, settings) that could be split into smaller, more focused classes.

Although relatively large in lines (LOC=193) and many fields (NOF=38, NOPF=38), complexity and behavior are minimal (NOM=1, WMC=1) and it appears to be a cohesive holder of intent constants/nested intent groups. Its single responsibility (intent definitions) argues against insufficient modularization.

Large size and complexity concentrated in one class: LOC=137 and WMC=33 indicate substantial internal logic; high number of fields (nof=22) and 10 methods (nom=10) suggest multiple responsibilities and internal state. Although LCOM=0.2 shows some cohesion, the class appears bloated and a likely candidate to be decomposed into smaller parser/helper classes to reduce complexity.

Moderate size and appears to act as an orchestrator/delegator: LOC=62, WMC=12, only 4 methods (nom=4) and few fields (nof=4). Dependencies show it delegates to BitMatrixParser and DecodedBitStreamParser and to reed-solomon utilities, indicating responsibilities are distributed rather than concentrated.
Small, focused utility: LOC=29, WMC=5, 2 methods (nom=2) and low field count (nof=2). Metrics indicate a narrowly scoped responsibility (parsing a BitMatrix), so it is sufficiently modular.
Very small class (LOC 9) with a single method and very low complexity (WMC 1). No evidence of concentrated responsibilities or a bloated interface.

Relatively large and stateful (LOC 118, 15 fields with 8 public), with a non-trivial method count (≈12) and moderate complexity (WMC 20). It exposes many fields/constants and is referenced by multiple decoder/encoder components, suggesting it aggregates several responsibilities that could be split (field definitions, factory/registry of presets, and operational behavior).

Very large and complex for a single class (LOC 220, WMC 49, ~12 methods). It represents heavy polynomial arithmetic logic and takes up a large portion of package LOC (220/530), indicating an abstraction that likely could be decomposed into smaller, more focused classes or helpers (e.g., separate construction, arithmetic operations, and utility routines).
Small and focused (LOC 46, ~3 methods, WMC 8). Metrics indicate a compact implementation with limited responsibilities, not suggesting insufficient modularization.

Moderately large and relatively complex (LOC 137, WMC 25) compared to other package classes. It implements multiple algorithmic steps (syndrome calculation, error locator/finders, correction) within one class, suggesting concentrated responsibilities that could be modularized into smaller collaborating classes or helpers.

Very large and complex class (loc=607, wmc=123) with many methods (nom=21) and many fields (nof=20). It depends on numerous other types and appears to centralize decoding responsibilities (many dependencies including decoders, data structures, and utilities), indicating multiple responsibilities concentrated in one class and a bloated interface that is hard to maintain and evolve.

Small and focused (loc=36, nom=7, wmc=8) with low complexity and LCOM indicating cohesion. It has few responsibilities and minimal dependencies, so it does not exhibit symptoms of insufficient modularization.
Compact utility-like class (loc=45, nom=2, wmc=11) with very few methods and focused purpose. Its size and cohesion suggest adequate modularization rather than excessive responsibility.

Small, cohesive data/utility class (loc=38, nom=8, wmc=9) with limited scope and dependencies. Metrics indicate it encapsulates a focused responsibility and does not concentrate excessive functionality.

Relatively small (loc 54) with few methods (nom 4, nopm 3) and moderate complexity (wmc 7). Appears to serve as a small utility/constants holder rather than a large, multi-responsibility abstraction, so there is no clear sign of inadequate decomposition at class level.

Moderate size and responsibility (loc 73, nom 10) but shows reasonable cohesion (lcom 0.2) and acts as a coordinator between detector/decoder components. Complexity (wmc 15) is acceptable for a reader/coordinator role and does not indicate a single bloated abstraction that needs decomposition.

High overall complexity concentrated in a small number of methods (loc 106, nom 5, wmc 21) indicating complex encoding logic is centralized in this class. The concentrated complexity and size suggest responsibilities that could be split into smaller encoder/utility classes to improve modularization.

Large public interface and many operations (loc 120, nom 22, nopm 22) with non-trivial complexity (wmc 22) and moderate cohesion (lcom 0.5). The number of fields and public methods indicates a bloated abstraction that likely mixes responsibilities and would benefit from decomposition into smaller, more focused classes.
Very small (loc 10) with few methods/fields (nom 1, nof 2); low complexity (wmc 1). Focused utility responsibilities, not indicative of poor modularization.

Relatively large and complex compared with peers (loc 121, nom 14, wmc 28, nof 5). High method count and complexity suggest multiple responsibilities or internal subdivisions that could be refactored into smaller, cohesive classes.
Tiny exception class (loc 9, nom 1, wmc 1). Purpose is narrowly scoped; does not indicate insufficient modularization.
Moderate size (loc 93, nom 9, wmc 20) but appears focused on a single domain responsibility (geolocation). Method and field counts are reasonable relative to purpose.
Small to moderate support class (loc 28, nom 5, wmc 5) acting as a source/provider. Limited size and complexity indicate adequate modularization.
Relatively small and focused (loc 44, nom 7, wmc 10). Complexity and method count are consistent with a single-responsibility generator.

Large and complex (loc 221, nom 20, wmc 46, nof 11). High method count, many fields, and high cyclomatic complexity indicate multiple responsibilities and a bloated class that would benefit from decomposition.
Moderate size but focused (loc 65, nom 8, wmc 14). Metrics are comparable to other specialized generators and do not by themselves indicate poor modularization.

Very large and complex (loc 235, nom 21, wmc 41, nof 14). High method/field counts and complexity suggest multiple concerns (parsing, validation, formatting, timezone handling) that could be split into smaller classes.

Substantial size and state (loc 194, nom 14, nof 14, wmc 18). Large number of fields combined with many public methods suggests a central/coordinating class that may be shouldering multiple responsibilities and could be decomposed.
Very small helper (loc 11, nom 1, wmc 1). Scoped responsibility (list of timezones) and minimal complexity indicate good modularization.
Small utility with focused purpose (loc 33, nom 6, wmc 10). Acts as a validation helper; size and responsibilities are limited and cohesive.
Small data/helper class (loc 24, nom 5, wmc 5). Single-responsibility and low complexity do not indicate insufficient modularization.
Small and focused (loc 46, nom 7, wmc 10). Comparable to other single-domain generators and appears adequately modularized.
Small and specialized (loc 43, nom 7, wmc 9). Limited complexity consistent with a single responsibility generator.
Small focused class (loc 47, nom 8, wmc 11). Complexity and size are modest and consistent with one-responsibility design.

Very large and complex: LOC=284, WMC=61, NOM=11. The class has many parsing responsibilities (depends on AddressBookParsedResult and VEventResultParser) and high cognitive complexity, indicating multiple responsibilities concentrated in one class that should be decomposed.

Centralized parsing logic with many methods and complexity: LOC=184, WMC=43, NOM=16, and many external dependencies. It likely implements multiple distinct parsing strategies in one place (wide interface and responsibilities), suggesting it should be split into smaller, focused parsers.

High complexity localized in one class: LOC=153, WMC=54, NOM=7. The substantial complexity and LOC indicate it encapsulates extensive validation/processing logic that could be modularized into smaller components (parsing, validation, formatting).

Small, focused data/result holder: LOC=51, WMC=9, NOM=7, LCOM=0.0. Metrics indicate a cohesive, limited-responsibility class representing a parsed URI rather than a bloated abstraction, so insufficient modularization is not indicated.

Moderate size and cohesive: LOC=60, WMC=10, NOM=10, LCOM=0.3. This class appears to be a parsed-result data holder with focused responsibilities rather than a large, multi-responsibility parser, so it does not show insufficient modularization.

Small class (loc 13) with a single abstraction (nom 1). Low overall footprint in the package and no evidence of many responsibilities or a bloated interface. Metrics do not indicate excessive complexity or size that would require further decomposition.

Dominates the package (224 of 237 LOC), with high complexity (WMC 47), many methods (nom 14) and several fields (nof 3). Low inheritance (DIT 0) and concentrated functionality suggest multiple responsibilities are bundled into one large class; this indicates inadequate decomposition and a need to split into smaller, more cohesive classes.
Very small class (LOC 17, WMC 2, 1 method/1 field). Low complexity and limited responsibilities, no evidence of being a bloated abstraction.
Small utility-like class (LOC 15, WMC 2, 2 methods). Size and complexity are low, appears focused on a single responsibility.
Moderate size (LOC 56, WMC 10, 4 methods) but not overly large or complex; responsibilities appear scoped to request filtering and DoS concerns.
Relatively small (LOC 43, WMC 7, 4 methods) and cohesive; no indications of excessive responsibilities or bloated interface.
Very small class (LOC 8, WMC 1, 1 method). Focused single responsibility, not a candidate for insufficient modularization.

Large and complex for a servlet (LOC 115, WMC 15) with multiple dependencies related to chart generation. Size and complexity suggest it mixes request handling and rendering responsibilities that could be decomposed (e.g., separate request parameter parsing, rendering, and image generation).

Very large and complex (LOC 349, WMC 41, 8 methods, 9 fields) with many dependencies. High LOC and complexity indicate multiple responsibilities (parsing input, decoding, error handling, DoS tracking) that would benefit from decomposition into smaller cohesive classes.
Small utility class (LOC 33, WMC 6, 3 methods). Focused on output concerns; size and cohesion do not indicate insufficient modularization.
Very small (LOC 5) likely a marker or lightweight filter; no evidence of bloated responsibilities.
Moderate LOC (85) but low complexity (WMC 4) and few methods (2). Likely focused on tracking DoS data; not evidently a bloated, multi-responsibility abstraction.
Inner task class (LOC 50) with low complexity; serves a specific background task responsibility rather than a large, multi-purpose abstraction.
Small base class (LOC 14, 3 methods) intended for reuse; its size and role as an abstraction do not indicate insufficient modularization.
Very small (LOC 5) and likely a thin specialization; no sign of excessive responsibilities.
Moderate size (LOC 38, WMC 7, 7 methods) but appears focused on parameter parsing/representation for chart servlet. Cohesive single responsibility, not a bloated abstraction.
Small utility/handler (LOC 31, WMC 6, 4 methods) with a focused purpose. Not indicative of insufficient modularization.

Very large implementation compared to peers (LOC 434) with many methods (nom 25) and very high cyclomatic/maintenance complexity (wmc 90). It depends on many collaborators and appears to concentrate multiple responsibilities (many dependencies) rather than delegating them, indicating inadequate decomposition.

Large class body (LOC 382) with many fields (nof 17) and substantial complexity (wmc 46). Presence of multiple nested helper types (VersionSize, Edge, ResultList, ResultNode) suggests attempts to pack related functionality in one top-level abstraction rather than separating into smaller focused classes, indicating insufficient modularization.
Very small (LOC 8) and appears to be a focused, supporting data abstraction for MinimalEncoder; size and role indicate adequate modularization at the class level.
Small helper (LOC 34) tightly scoped to MinimalEncoder logic; its limited size and focused dependencies suggest it is an appropriate decomposition rather than a sign of insufficient modularization.

Contains a moderate amount of code (LOC 170) but exists as a dedicated nested type representing a specific responsibility (result management). Its separation from the main encoder logic is an indication of modularization rather than a single bloated class.
Relatively small (LOC 79) and appears to be a focused node/data structure supporting MinimalEncoder; represents proper decomposition into a helper abstraction.
Very small (LOC 14) with few methods and fields, indicating a single, focused responsibility and appropriate modularization.

Moderate-to-large utility (LOC 161) with notable complexity (wmc 38) and a relatively higher lack-of-cohesion score compared to other classes (lcom 0.6667), suggesting it bundles multiple masking/utility behaviors that could be split into more focused components.

Substantial size (LOC 226), many methods (nom 20) and high complexity (wmc 55) for a utility-like class. It depends on multiple encoder artifacts, indicating it may combine multiple responsibilities that would benefit from further decomposition.
Relatively small (LOC 61) with a modest number of methods and fields; appears to be a focused data/utility type used by other classes, which indicates acceptable modularization.

Small to moderate size (LOC 72) with modest complexity and cohesion (lcom 0.0). It appears to represent a single abstraction (the QR code model) and does not show signs of being a bloated, multi-responsibility class.

Very large class (loc 405) with high complexity (wmc 65) and many fields/members (nof 21). Contains multiple nested helper types and substantial encoding logic (multiple responsibilities) indicating a bloated abstraction that could be split into smaller, focused components (e.g., encoder, strategy, utilities).

Large and complex reader (loc 326, wmc 79, nof 16). Handles a wide range of decoding logic and depends on many result/format concerns, suggesting concentrated responsibilities that would benefit from decomposition into smaller, cohesive classes (parsing, checksum, state machine).

Relatively large class (loc 279, wmc 40, nof 10, nom 13) with many dependencies and extension handling (extension support, manufacturer support, multiple writer/reader interactions). It aggregates multiple concerns (core decode, extensions, metadata) and appears to be doing more than a single cohesive role.

Substantial size and complexity (loc 254, wmc 52, nom 8, nof 7) with responsibilities including decoding, checksum/format handling and metadata production. The combination of high complexity and multiple responsibilities indicates poor decomposition.

Significant size/complexity (loc 221, wmc 47) and multiple responsibilities related to decoding and format/metadata handling. Its complexity suggests it could be split into helper components (e.g., pattern recognition, checksum, result assembly).

Moderate size (loc 196, wmc 32, nom 8) but represents a core abstract/base reader used by many concrete readers (nc 8). Its role is a shared abstraction; its size corresponds to shared behavior rather than a concentration of unrelated responsibilities, so it is reasonably modular for that purpose.

Non-trivial nested helper (loc 160) but purpose-built for encoding optimization. Although sizeable, it is focused on a single concern (minimal encoding) and implemented as an internal component of Code128Writer, so splitting it out further is optional and not clearly required for modularization.
Small and focused writer (loc 52, nom 2, wmc 8) with a narrow responsibility. Low size and cohesion indicate no insufficient modularization smell.
Small writer class (loc 54, nom 2) with focused responsibility; its size and single-purpose nature do not indicate insufficient modularization.
Very small utility writer (loc 16, nom 2) with a single, cohesive role; no signs of bloated responsibilities.

Large size and complexity (loc=190, wmc=15, nof=14) and contains an embedded NetworkTask. Mixes UI logic with network/search responsibilities (depends on HttpHelper, LocaleManager, Intents), indicating concentrated responsibilities and poor decomposition.

Substantial nested class (loc=94) that performs network-related work (depends on HttpHelper) inside the activity. Large inner class suggests a responsibility that should be modularized into a separate component.
Small and simple (loc=27, nom=2, wmc=4) with limited responsibilities and few methods; no evidence of a bloated interface or excessive complexity.
Moderate size/complexity for a list item (loc=48, nom=4, wmc=8) and low cohesion (lcom=0.75), indicating multiple responsibilities within a single class and potential need to split concerns.
Small listener class (loc=28, nom=2, wmc=5) with focused responsibilities; no signs of excessive size or a bloated interface.
Relatively compact and cohesive (loc=35, nom=7, wmc=7, lcom≈0.29); appears to be a focused result/data holder rather than an overly large, multi-responsibility class.

Small size (loc 32), low complexity (wmc 6), high cohesion (lcom 0.0) and acts primarily as a result/data holder with few dependencies. The class appears focused on a single responsibility and is not excessively bloated.

Relatively high complexity (wmc 13) and moderate size (loc 54) while exposing few methods (nom 4), suggesting large/multi‑purpose methods. Dependencies include encoder and aztec code types and BitMatrix, indicating it both prepares data and performs encoding/matrix assembly. These characteristics imply concentrated responsibilities and insufficient decomposition into smaller, more focused classes or helper components.

Largest class in the package (loc 75) with notable complexity (wmc 11) and a wide set of dependencies (detector, result types, exceptions, callbacks, decode/format types). Although it has few declared methods (nom 3), the complexity and breadth of collaborators indicate it orchestrates detection, decoding, error handling and metadata assembly within the same abstraction, suggesting insufficient modularization and opportunities to split responsibilities.

Large public surface (12 methods, 11 public), substantial size (105 LOC) and non-trivial complexity (WMC 17). Acts as a broad abstraction with many public operations used by many components, indicating an interface that groups multiple responsibilities rather than narrower, more cohesive abstractions.

Relatively large concrete class (103 LOC) with many public methods (9 methods, 8 public) and high complexity (WMC 20) combined with low cohesion (LCOM 0.222). The metrics suggest it handles multiple concerns (pixel format handling, cropping/rotation, conversion, etc.) and would benefit from further decomposition.

Broad public API (11 methods, 11 public) and moderate size (95 LOC) with low cohesion (LCOM 0.0). It connects binarization and higher-level decoding consumers and has many dependents, suggesting it consolidates responsibilities that could be separated for clearer modularization.

Large exposed interface (14 methods, 14 public), significant complexity (WMC 19) and zero cohesion measure (LCOM 0.0) plus many external dependents. These signs indicate a bloated data/behavior holder combining multiple kinds of metadata and logic that could be split into smaller, focused abstractions.

Substantial size (126 LOC) with very high complexity (WMC 26). Although method count is modest, the complexity implies it orchestrates many decoding strategies and concerns. This coordination role appears to aggregate responsibilities that could be modularized into clearer strategy/handler components.

Moderate size (89 LOC) and method count (8 methods, 7 public) with reasonable cohesion (LCOM 0.375). As a concrete subclass focused on grayscale conversion, its responsibilities appear focused and cohesive rather than overly broad.
Very small and simple (25 LOC, 2 methods, WMC 4). Metrics indicate a focused, single-purpose implementation rather than a bloated abstraction, so insufficient modularization is not indicated.
Very small class (LOC 12, WMC 1, NOM 1) with few responsibilities and low complexity; does not show signs of being a bloated abstraction.
Relatively large and complex for its scope (LOC 81, NOM 5, WMC 27) and depends on field/formatter classes; high WMC indicates multiple responsibilities or complex logic that could be decomposed.
Moderate size and complexity (LOC 40, NOM 4, WMC 9) and focused on a single formatting concern, suggesting adequate modularization.
Moderate metrics (LOC 50, NOM 5, WMC 11) and limited dependencies; while it coordinates encoding, its size/complexity do not strongly indicate an undecomposed abstraction.

Large Android activity (LOC 159, NOM 7, WMC 21) with substantial logic; activities that combine UI handling and encoding behavior can be signs of insufficient separation of concerns and may warrant refactoring.

Very large and complex class (LOC 266, NOM 15, WMC 57) with many external dependencies and responsibilities related to parsing/encoding; metrics indicate a likely god-class that should be decomposed into smaller, cohesive abstractions.
Small, focused utility-like class (LOC 46, NOM 4, WMC 10) serving a single formatting role; does not appear to be an insufficiently modularized abstraction.
Relatively small (LOC 41, NOM 1, WMC 1) with nested formatter classes; the nesting suggests contained, cohesive functionality rather than an overlarge abstraction.
Very small nested helper (LOC 7, WMC 0) dedicated to a narrow formatting role; no evidence of bloated responsibility.
Tiny nested formatter (LOC 6, WMC 0) focused on a single display concern; appropriately modular.
Tiny nested formatter (LOC 6, WMC 0) with a narrow responsibility; does not exhibit insufficient modularization.
Small class (loc 39) with few methods (nom 6), low complexity (wmc 11) and focused dependencies on ParsedResult/Result — appears cohesive and single-responsibility.
Very small (loc 27) factory with few methods (nom 3) and focused role of creating handlers; size and responsibilities do not indicate insufficient modularization.
Small (loc 28), few methods (nom 5), and depends specifically on EmailAddressParsedResult — focused on a single concern.
Small (loc 32), limited methods (nom 5), low complexity (wmc 9) and single responsibility (text handling).
Small (loc 28), few methods (nom 5), focused dependency on GeoParsedResult — cohesive and narrowly scoped.
Relatively small (loc 32) with limited methods (nom 5) and clear single-responsibility (ISBN parsing/handling).

Clear outlier: very large (loc 361), very high complexity (wmc 80), many methods (nom 43) and low cohesion (lcom 0.186). It aggregates many responsibilities and dependencies (multiple managers, parsers, activities), indicating it is under-modularized and should be decomposed into smaller, cohesive classes.
Moderate size (loc 50) and methods (nom 7) with focused dependency on URIParsedResult and LocaleManager — appears single-purpose and cohesive.
Very small (loc 15), low complexity (wmc 2), and single responsibility (button listener) — not a modularization issue.
Small (loc 42), limited methods (nom 6) and specific to SMSParsedResult — focused and cohesive.

Larger than other handlers (loc 126, wmc 26, nom 8) but still focused on AddressBookParsedResult. Size/complexity reflect handling of richer data rather than clear multi-responsibility aggregation; no strong evidence it needs further decomposition given context.
Small (loc 36), few methods (nom 6) and narrowly focused on telephone parsed results — cohesive single responsibility.
Small to moderate (loc 45, nom 7) and targeted at WifiParsedResult with limited dependencies — appears modular and cohesive.

Moderate size (loc 104, nom 8, wmc 18) but dedicated to CalendarParsedResult. Although more complex than simple handlers, it represents a single domain concern rather than an undivided multi-responsibility class.

Small class (loc 55) with few methods (nom 4, nopm 3). Although WMC is moderate (16), Mode models a focused concept (QR encoding modes) and has low coupling indicators; complexity appears inherent to the domain rather than an indicator of multiple responsibilities.

Very large and complex: highest LOC (261) and very high cyclomatic complexity (WMC 61) with 9 methods. Handles multi-format parsing concerns and depends on many decoder-related types. These signs (size, high WMC, multiple responsibilities implied by dependencies) indicate it concentrates parsing logic that could be decomposed into smaller, focused parser components.
Small (loc 35) with few methods (nom 3, nopm 2) and low complexity (WMC 4). Represents a single abstraction (EC level) and its interface size is appropriate to the concept.

Moderate size (loc 114) and complexity (WMC 13, nom 7). Its responsibilities (error correction, data block handling, invoking parsers) align with a single decoding abstraction; metrics do not clearly show a mix of unrelated responsibilities that would warrant decomposition.

Relatively large (loc 163, nom 12, WMC 23) but models a rich domain concept (QR Code version, EC blocks) with nested types (ECBlocks, ECB). Low LCOM indicates cohesion; public method count (nopm 8) reflects the needed API for the concept rather than fragmented responsibilities.
Very small helper/nested type (loc 27) closely tied to Version. It encapsulates a focused part of the Version abstraction and does not show signs of being a bloated multi-responsibility class.
Tiny nested class (loc 17) representing a single concept related to Version; no evidence of multiple responsibilities.

Moderate size (loc 73) with a small set of methods (nom 4) and concentrated responsibilities around data block representation and handling; metrics do not indicate a bloated interface or mixed concerns.

Large and complex (loc 175, WMC 35, nom 8). It combines responsibilities for matrix parsing, format/version extraction and interacts with several decoder components. The size and complexity concentrated in one class suggest opportunities to split parsing, format interpretation and version extraction into smaller modules.

Moderate size (loc 76, nom 8, WMC 16) focused on format information concerns. LCOM and the nature of dependencies suggest cohesion around a single responsibility (format info), not a sign of insufficient modularization.

Contains multiple mask algorithms (nom 10) but these are conceptually related and typically implemented together; loc 84 and WMC 13 reflect algorithmic variations rather than mixed, unrelated responsibilities.
Very small (loc 28, nom 3, WMC 4) and focused on decoder metadata. No indicators of excessive size or multiple unrelated responsibilities.

IntentIntegrator is substantially larger and more complex than its peer: 325 LOC, 34 methods (nom), 24 fields (nof), and a high WMC of 61. It also exposes many public members (nopm = 27, nopf = 12), indicating a bloated interface. These characteristics (high size, many methods/fields, many public API elements and high complexity) suggest it concentrates multiple responsibilities and would benefit from decomposition into smaller, more focused classes.

IntentResult is small and focused: 55 LOC, 8 methods, 5 fields and modest complexity (WMC = 8). Its interface and size are limited, indicating it represents a cohesive, single responsibility and does not exhibit signs of insufficient modularization.

Moderate size and complexity (loc 95, wmc 16) with a small public surface (nom 5, nopm 3), limited number of fields (nof 2) and moderate cohesion (lcom 0.4). Dependencies are focused on decoding-related types, indicating responsibilities are cohesive and not excessively concentrated in this class.

Relatively large and complex implementation (loc 138, wmc 25) despite a small method count (nom 4), suggesting large/multi-responsibility methods. It depends on many encoder-related components (HighLevelEncoder, DefaultPlacement, ErrorCorrection, MinimalEncoder, SymbolInfo, etc.), indicating it centralizes multiple encoding responsibilities that could be decomposed into smaller, more focused classes.

Large size and high complexity: 219 LOC and WMC=41 indicate substantial implementation complexity concentrated in one class; 9 fields and 6 methods suggest many responsibilities/state. The class depends on multiple domain types (BitMatrix, ResultPoint, MathUtils) implying it orchestrates different concerns rather than a small cohesive role. These factors point to insufficient decomposition.

Small, focused utility: 50 LOC, 5 methods and low complexity (WMC=6). Although used by many detectors, its small size and narrow purpose (math/helper operations) indicate appropriate modularization rather than an overlarge, multifaceted abstraction.

Moderate size and cohesion: 147 LOC with WMC=21 is smaller and less complex than the flagged class; only 2 fields and 4 methods suggest a focused responsibility. Lacking signs of a bloated interface or many unrelated responsibilities, it appears reasonably decomposed for its purpose.

Very large and complex class: 402 LOC out of the package's 436 LOC (dominates the package), WMC = 48 (high cyclomatic complexity), 20 methods (many responsibilities). It depends on many unrelated modules (reedsolomon, common.detector.MathUtils, GridSampler, BitMatrix, AztecReader, etc.), and defines nested helper classes (Point, CorrectedParameter), indicating multiple responsibilities concentrated in one abstraction. These factors indicate inadequate decomposition and a bloated abstraction.

Small, focused inner class: 20 LOC, no methods, minimal complexity and dependencies (only references the outer Detector). Appears to be a simple data holder tied to Detector rather than a large, separate responsibility that needs further decomposition.
Very small and narrowly scoped: 14 LOC, no methods, low complexity, and only used in context of Detector. Serves as a small helper/structure rather than an under-modularized abstraction.

Relatively small implementation (LOC 64) with moderate complexity (WMC 8), few fields (1) and methods (5), low coupling in the available metrics and good cohesion (LCOM 0.0). These characteristics indicate a focused responsibility rather than a bloated, insufficiently decomposed abstraction.

Largest and most complex class in the package (LOC 103, WMC 24) with multiple fields (4) and multiple methods; it concentrates the core logic for handling multiple barcode detection in a small package (3 classes). The relatively high complexity and size compared to peers suggest responsibilities could be further decomposed, indicating insufficient modularization.

Very small abstraction (LOC 9, WMC 2) with only two declared methods and likely an interface-like role (nom 2, LCOM -1.0). It does not exhibit signs of excessive size or crowded responsibilities and therefore does not show insufficient modularization.
Very small (loc 17), few methods (nom 3), low complexity (wmc 3) and LCOM 0.0 indicating cohesion; represents a focused, lightweight abstraction so there is no sign it needs further decomposition.

Very large and complex for the package (loc 320 — ~43% of package LOC), many methods (nom 15) and high cyclomatic complexity (wmc 65). This concentration and size suggest the abstraction is insufficiently modularized.

Moderate size (loc 56), moderate method count (nom 10) and low complexity (wmc 10) with reasonable cohesion (LCOM 0.5). Appears to be a data/representation holder collaborating with Encoder and writer rather than a bloated, multi-responsibility class.

Relatively large (loc 180 — ~24% of package LOC) with substantial complexity (wmc 33) and many fields/methods (nof 11, nom 9). Small (loc 17) with few methods (nom 5) and modest complexity (wmc 5). Although LCOM is higher (0.8), the class is small and likely models a compact part of the token hierarchy; it does not exhibit the excessive size or complexity typical of insufficient modularization.
Small (loc 30), low-to-moderate complexity (wmc 7) and cohesive (LCOM 0.0). It appears to be a focused subclass of Token with a single responsibility, so no modularization issue is evident.

Substantial size for a helper/utility within the encoder (loc 130 — ~17% of package LOC), many methods (nom 14) and notable complexity (wmc 28). It depends on Token and HighLevelEncoder and likely encapsulates multiple aspects of encoder state management and transitions. The concentration of behavior and nontrivial size suggests it should be decomposed or have responsibilities redistributed.

Relatively large (loc=51) and complex (wmc=9) while showing low cohesion (lcom=1.0). Complexity is concentrated in a small number of methods (nom=2, nopm=1), indicating multiple responsibilities or heavy internal branching that could be decomposed into smaller, more focused abstractions.

Relatively small (loc=27) with moderate complexity (wmc=5) and high cohesion (lcom=0.0). It has a focused set of methods (nom=5, nopm=5) and no signs of bloated interface or dispersed responsibilities, so insufficient modularization is not indicated.
Tiny, trivial abstraction (loc=4) with no fields or methods (nof=0, nom=0) and no complexity (wmc=0). Its minimal size and likely role as an enum/constant holder indicate appropriate modularization.

The class is large and complex (loc: 249, WMC: 32) which indicates substantial internal logic. It declares 11 methods but only 2 public methods (nom: 11, nopm: 2), suggesting many internal/private helpers and multiple responsibilities concentrated in the same class. The class has few fields (nof: 2) and no subclasses (nc: 0), implying functionality is implemented as behavior rather than cleanly separated abstractions. Its dependencies (WhiteRectangleDetector, BitMatrix, GridSampler, etc.) show it orchestrates several distinct detection/sampling concerns. Taken together, size, high complexity, many non-public methods and cross-cutting responsibilities justify that Detector is insufficiently modularized and would benefit from decomposition into smaller, more focused classes.
Small data-holder class (loc 29, nom 3, wmc 5) with low complexity and high cohesion (lcom 0.0). Limited dependencies and few methods indicate a single, focused responsibility.

Large and complex class (loc 200, nom 13, nopm 8, wmc 24) with many dependencies across UI, persistence, and supplemental-info retrievers. Small adapter with low complexity (loc 33, nom 2, wmc 4) and few responsibilities. Its limited surface and focused dependencies suggest adequate modularization.

Small helper (loc 24, nom 3, wmc 3) whose higher field count likely represents constants/configuration rather than multiple responsibilities. Concentrated database-related role and modest complexity indicate acceptable modularization.

UI controller of moderate size (loc 104, nom 9, wmc 17) but typical for an Activity. It delegates to HistoryManager and adapters; cohesion is high (lcom 0.0) and responsibilities appear UI-focused rather than a sign of an overly-bloated abstraction.
Very small class (loc 18) with few methods (nom 3) and low complexity (wmc 3); appears to be a simple data/transfer abstraction rather than a bloated abstraction.

Moderate size (loc 110) and moderate complexity (nom 9, wmc 21) but focused on ECI encoder responsibilities and few external dependencies; does not present signs of multiple unrelated responsibilities.

Relatively large and complex for its method count (loc 145, nom 7, wmc 33, nopm 3) suggesting heavy internal logic; elevated complexity concentrated in few methods indicates multiple responsibilities or internal branches that could be factored out (e.g., local vs global thresholding logic).

Very large and complex (LOC 372, WMC 71, 11 methods). Moderate size (LOC 115, WMC 15, 11 methods) but represents a cohesive abstraction (version metadata/EC blocks). Its responsibilities appear focused on version/EC block information rather than multiple unrelated concerns.

Class is small (31 LOC) with a modest number of methods (5) and moderate complexity (WMC=6). Cohesion is reasonable (LCOM=0.4), no inheritance (DIT=0), and coupling is low at class level (fanin=0, fanout=0) despite two external references. These indicators point to a focused, lightweight abstraction rather than a bloated, multifunctional class, so insufficient modularization is not detected.

ModulusPoly concentrates substantial size and complexity within the package: highest LOC (192) and highest WMC (46) among the three classes, with 13 methods. It represents nearly half of the package's LOC and exposes many operations related to polynomial arithmetic, suggesting multiple responsibilities (construction, arithmetic ops, utilities) that could be split into smaller, more focused abstractions. Its heavy mutual dependencies with ModulusGF and ErrorCorrection further indicate a central, bloated role rather than a narrowly scoped class.

Although ErrorCorrection has moderate complexity (LOC 129, WMC 23), it exposes a small public interface (few public methods/nopm = 2) and a modest number of methods overall (nom = 5), indicating a focused responsibility (the error-correction algorithm). LCOM = 0.0 suggests internal cohesion. Contextual judgment favors it being a cohesive algorithmic component rather than an insufficiently modular class.

ModulusGF is relatively small (LOC 75) with a limited number of fields and methods oriented around finite-field arithmetic (nom = 11, nof = 6). Its responsibilities (field arithmetic/lookup tables) are conceptually cohesive and narrowly scoped; while it is used by the other classes, its size and focused role do not indicate inadequate modularization in this package context.

This class accounts for the vast majority of the package (92 of 99 LOC) and has a relatively high WMC (16), indicating concentrated complexity in a single abstraction. It depends on several unrelated types (DetectorResult, DecoderResult, Result, BinaryBitmap, etc.), suggesting it coordinates multiple responsibilities. The presence of an inner comparator class and relatively few named methods but large LOC implies methods are doing substantial work rather than functionality being split into smaller cohesive classes—characteristics of insufficient modularization.

Very small helper class (7 LOC) with negligible complexity; appears to be a focused, single-responsibility comparator used by the reader. Its small size and scoped role make it an appropriate internal component rather than a sign of insufficient modularization.

Concentrates substantial size and complexity in a single class: 259 LOC and a high WMC of 42 indicate complex implementation. It has a large number of fields (nof=13) and a moderate number of methods (nom=9) which, together with the package having only two classes, suggests responsibilities are concentrated rather than decomposed. Dependency usage (ResultPoint, PDF417Reader, BinaryBitmap, BitMatrix, PDF417DetectorResult) and the low number of sibling classes increase the likelihood this class is a bloated abstraction that should be split into smaller, more focused components.

Small and cohesive: only 25 LOC, low complexity (WMC=5), few fields (nof=3) and methods (nom=5), and LCOM=0.0 indicating high cohesion. Its narrowly scoped role (packaging detection results) and light weight make it unlikely to suffer from insufficient modularization.

Much larger and more complex than its peers (loc 121, WMC 25, NOM 8) and higher lack-of-cohesion (LCOM 0.625). Small and focused (loc 53, WMC 7, NOM 2) with LCOM 0.0 and limited, specific dependencies. Metrics and role indicate a single responsibility (retrieving book info), so it does not show signs of insufficient modularization.

Small and simple (loc 26, WMC 3, NOM 2, LCOM 0.0) with narrow dependencies; it appears to implement a focused responsibility and does not exhibit signs of being insufficiently modularized.

Modest size and complexity (loc 35, WMC 6, NOM 2) and high cohesion (LCOM 0.0). Its metrics and focused dependency set suggest a single responsibility (retrieving titles), so it does not suffer from insufficient modularization.

Very large class (loc 536) with high complexity (WMC 107) and many methods (nom 22). Small (loc 23, nom 4, WMC 4) and appears to encapsulate information about finder patterns. Its limited scope and low complexity indicate it is modular and cohesive.

Small (10 LOC) with few fields and no measured complexity; serves a focused role as a simple data/result holder for the Decoder, not exhibiting excessive size or mixed responsibilities.
